prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W0116-0505 Spectral imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band-3 CO imaging of host galaxy of ELIRG W0116-0505

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A mix of continuum and line detection search. Obtaining the maximum bandwidth for continuum observations is important. The nominal linewidth of 500 km/s (Bothwell et al. 2013) is entered, sufficient to ensure that the representative spectral resolution of 84.8 km/s gives several resolution elements across the line.

We would like to resolve the host galaxy from the hot central regions of the AGN. To that end, we have selected 0.35 arcseconds as the target resolution. This ensures that we should obtain excellent spatial resolution, obtaining several independent pixels across the host, without special long-baseline configurations.
We know that the regions around ELIRGs/HotDOGs contain companions. 3 arcsec is entered as a reasonable value for the largest angular scale. It is possible that there are companions that can be found to larger distances, given the large primary beam in Band-3, many of these should be identified.

This sensitivity calculation describes the assumed situation for the targets, which are expected to be comparable in brightness. The available continuum observations for our ELIRG targets (Tsai et al. 2015) - selected as the most luminous Herschel-observed WISE HotDOGs - obtained by Wu et al. (2012) and Jones et al. (2014) indicate that 850-micron fluxes are expected to be ~8mJy. This corresponds to a very luminous host galaxy, that would be classed as an SMG, being outshone only by the very great mid-IR power of the ELIRG targets (see Tsai et al. 2015).
The sensitivity is chosen to give a suitable S/N ratio for the detection of CO(4-3) at z~3-4, assuming that the cool ISM emits mostly in the Rayleigh-Jeans regime, has a CO SLED that peaks at ~(5-4) and follows the excitation typical for an SMG/DSG.
Line widths of 400-500 km/s are typical for SMGs (Bothwell et al. 2013), and consistent with our IRAM data on HotDOGs (Blain et al. 2015).
Expected total CO(4-3) line luminosities are 1.5 Jy km/s, following Bothwell et al.'s CO(4-3) sources, matching the 8mJy continuum level of our targets, and accounting for the higher redshift of the ELIRGs.
We expect the 3mm thermal continuum emission from the host galaxy to be faint, about 0.2mJy; however, we expect there to be little prospect of detecting the crucial molecular line emission from the typical interstellar medium in the host galaxy at higher frequencies, as higher-J lines are not expected to be excited, based upon our existing submm-wave limits to these galaxies' properties, based on the line excitation measured by Danielson et al. (2011, MNRAS, 410, 1869), Bothwell et al. (2013, MNRAS, 429, 3047) and Spilker et al. (2014, ApJ, 785, 149).
The depth expected to image the CO(4-3) line is well-matched to making a useful detection of the continuum. Assuming a 500 km/s line, with a peak flux density of 3mJy, and a continuum flux of 0.2mJy requires a sensitivity per pointing of 0.3mJy in a 500 km/s band, or about 0.05mJy over an 7.5-GHz band to obtain a line detection at a S/N of 10, and a continuum detection at S/N of 5. In order to obtain spectral resolution and imaging quality over 4-5 resolution elements, we seek a sensitivity sufficient to obtain a total S/N of 15, and so we set the sensitivity to 0.015mJy over an 7.5-GHz band.
Where possible, the LO setting is chosen to ensure that the continuum bands are as high in frequency as possible, with the CO line being in the lowest available setting.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: See the calculations discussed for Science Goal 1, ELIRG W0116-0505. Our sources have comparable brightness and properties.
See the calculations discussed for Science Goal 1, ELIRG W0116-0505. Our sources have comparable brightness and properties.

See the calculations discussed for Science Goal 1, ELIRG W0116-0505. Our sources have comparable brightness and properties.
A different line is targeted in W2246-0526, CO(5-4), owing to the greater redshift of this source. Bothwell et al. (2013) indicates that CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) are within 20% of brightness. The additional redshift almost counteracts the greater line brightness expected, and we leave the control and performance requirements unchanged.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: All-sky mid-IR selection in the WISE survey has highlighted an extremely luminous population of "HotDOGs": powerful AGN with a characteristic hot SED, and luminosities reaching above ten to the fourteen times solar. They have redshifts, well-defined SEDs and FIR luminosities, and they are as numerous as optically-selected QSOs. HotDOGs have very-obscured AGN-dominated SEDs, very different from those of low-redshift ULIRGs or high-redshift SMGs/DSGs. We propose to probe the nature of the ISM in their host galaxies in Band-3. This will provide crucial information about their fuelling, morphology, state of evolution and dynamics. The HotDOGs are the MOST extreme galaxies, forming and feeding-back at the very greatest rate: we will catch a spectral snapshot of the most detectable CO line from the bulk of the molecular gas in their host galaxies, the immediate region of the AGN, and any outflowing gas. We will find their host's ISM properties, for comparison with our growing picture of their stellar and BH masses. These observations should reveal the processes that power the most dramatically luminous galaxies, and which perhaps bring their extremely luminous phase to an end.
